docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: To foster arguments that employers should not support employee health insurance, the column says private insurance suppresses creation of new jobs and depresses wages. It also says that all this private welfare goes back to World War II, when companies started offering medical insurance to woo workers.

headline.main: Health Insurance, But Provided by Whom?

docs.lead_paragraph: NO doubt, the shakeup of two of the largest insurance companies in the state is big news here. The companies, Travelers and CIGNA, employ thousands of people here and bring billions of dollars to the state's economy. When the industry makes a major move, people in the state hold their breath. But does Connecticut live by insurance alone?
docs.abstract: Article on impact that shakeup of Travelers and CIGNA, two of largest companies in Connecticut, may have on state; Hartford-based Travelers announced merger with St Paul Companies, based in Minnesota, and CIGNA has decided to sell its retirement plan business to Prudential Financial; while two companies employ thousands of people, state is no longer insurance capital of world; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In ''The Universal Cure'' (Op-Ed, Nov. 18), Ezekiel J. Emanuel and Victor R. Fuchs do not note one important disadvantage of employer-based health insurance: its failure to provide adequate preventive coverage (which can save lives and costs), especially to workers in high-turnover service-sector jobs. Employers are reluctant to pay since a worker's future employer would reap the benefits.
docs.abstract: Prof Warren Greenberg letter on Ezekiel J Emanuel and Victor R Fuchs Nov 18 article cites added disadvantage of employer-based health insurance

docs.lead_paragraph: As a television game-show host, Ben Stein regularly gave away his own money to winning contestants. But now he's worried about baby boomers' money. ''We have a disgraceful situation on the part of individuals refusing to face reality and save enough for their retirement,'' Mr. Stein, the comedian, said last week.

headline.main: Business People; Ben Stein Is Worried About Your Money

byline.original: By MICHELINE MAYNARD; Julie Dunn contributed reporting from Denver

docs.lead_paragraph: WITH 35 million members more than one-tenth the population of the United States -- AARP, the organization representing retirees, has long been the 800-pound gorilla in the Medicare prescription drug debate. So when the group endorsed a Republican-backed Medicare bill last week, Democrats reacted with anger and alarm. Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, the Democratic leader in the House, complained that AARP was ''in the pocket'' of Republicans, and suggested that the group, which also sells insurance to its members, had a financial conflict of interest. Eighty-five House Democrats announced they would either resign from AARP, or refuse to join.

headline.main: Ideas & Trends; An 800-Pound Gorilla Changes Partners Over Medicare

docs.abstract: AARP's support of Republican Medicare prescription drug bill reflects in part views of aging baby boomers, who are far less committed to Democratic Party position than AARP's oldest members; AARP also extracted price for its support: bigger subsidies for low-income people and incentives for employers to continue offering drug benefits; photo (M)
docs.snippet: WITH 35 million members  more than one-tenth the population of the United States -- AARP, the organization representing retirees, has long been the 800-pound gorilla in the Medicare prescription drug debate. So when the group endorsed a...

docs.lead_paragraph: For some conservative Republicans opposed to expanding a government entitlement program, the sweetener that allowed them to swallow the medicine and vote for the Medicare bill on Saturday morning was the inclusion of a new tax-free health savings account. These accounts have long been a goal of conservative lawmakers and academics who want to add cost-cutting competition to the health insurance marketplace and offer a way for workers to save money for medical expenses in their retirement.

headline.main: Tax-Free Accounts Drew Yeas From the Wary
headline.kicker: A FINAL PUSH IN CONGRESS: THE SAVINGS PLAN

docs.abstract: Conservative House Republicans opposed to expanding government entitlement programs agree to vote for Medicare bill with inclusion of new tax-free health savings account; conservative lawmakers and academics have long sought such accounts as way to add cost-cutting competition to health insurance marketplace and offer way for workers to save money for medical expenses in their retirement; opponents of savings account measure, mostly liberal Democrats, see it as tax shelter for young, healthy and wealthy people and potential trap for unwary workers (M)
docs.snippet: For some conservative Republicans opposed to expanding a government entitlement program, the sweetener that allowed them to swallow the medicine and vote for the Medicare bill on Saturday morning was the inclusion of a new tax-free health savings...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Wal-Mart's cost-cutting techniques (''The Wal-Martization of America,'' editorial, Nov. 15) are widespread. Nearly 30 million American workers -- one in four -- earn wages that keep them below the federal poverty line for a family of four, unable to provide for themselves and their families. As taxpayers, we involuntarily subsidize their employers with the food stamps, child care and housing vouchers and other support their employees rely on to make ends meet.

docs.lead_paragraph: A divided House debated legislation into the night on Friday that would make the biggest changes to Medicare since its creation in 1965. The bill cleared a key procedural hurdle shortly before midnight, but the Bush administration and Republican leaders were racing to round up votes to the very end. In the Senate, the Democratic leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, said Friday that he would not support a filibuster against the bill, which increased the chances for final action on the legislation within days.

headline.main: As House Debate Continues, Medicare Bill Nears Vote

docs.abstract: Divided House debates bill to overhaul Medicare and add prescription drug benefit; Bush administration and Republican leadership race to round up votes that enable bill to clear key procedural hurdle; Senate Democratic leader, Tom Daschle, says he will not back filibuster against bill, increasing chances for final action on bill within days; House Democratic leaders pressure Democrats to vote against bill, which they say would undermine and privatize Medicare; Republican leaders insist bill is last, best chance to provide long-promised drug benefits, news conference; conservatives are restless and Democrats furious that bill, written by Republicans in closed-door meetings, is being pushed through House with little debate; photo (M)
